intro: Horkelia cuneata var. puberula, commonly known as the hairy foothill gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Polemoniaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces showy, blue to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. Its botanical features make it well adapted to arid environments and suitable for xeriscaping.
